VOL. XXXI, No. 49

DR, Li WARDLAW MILES
TO BE ENGLISH HEAD
Former Head-master of Gilman
Succeeds Dr. French
DEPARTMENT REORGANIZED

Only Two Courses Offered to
Students in College
Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, formerly
head-master of the Gilman Country
School and now a lecturer at this
University, has been appointed to
succeed Dr. John C. French as Collegiate Professor of English. Dr.
Miles' appointment and,several other
major changes in the department of
English are the result 6f a complete
reorganization which that department has recently undergone in the
establishment of the New Plan,
Which the University is gradually
adopting.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1927

CANE CLUB ELECTS
FIVE NEW MEMBERS
Miller Sherwood, Emmert
Stuart, Donald Hiss, Heyward Boyce and Stewart
Hawkes were elected members of the Cane Club last
week. The customary tapping and initiation was held
Monday at noon.
Following the ceremonies
on the upper quadrangle the
members of the club held a
luncheon followed by a
dance that night.
Sherwood, Stuart and
Hiss are members of the
sophomore class while Boyce
is a senior and Hawkes a
graduate student.

Tudor-Stuart Club
Elects New Officers

Hopkins Graduate

Dr. Miles received _his_A. B. at
Johns Hopkins in 1894. He later
studied medicine at the University
of Maryland, and received his degree there. Finding himself more in
Sympathy with the study of literature than of medicine, he returned
to this University, where he received
his doctor's degree in literature in
1902.
After securing this degree here,
Dr. Miles taught for a while at the.
Country School. Later he went to
Princeton where he was instructor
and then preceptor in English until
the outbreak of the World War.
Serving with the American forces
in France as a captain, he was
awarded the Congressional Medal,
for distinguished bravery.
Returns to City

After the Armistice, when he had
sufficiently recovered from wounds
suffered during hostilities, he became head-master of Gilman Country School from which position he
resigned last June. For the past
Year he has been lecturing at St.
John's College and here.
Dr. Miles will head the College
Department of English and be assisted by two instructors and five
student assistants. As a result of the
complete reorganization, which it
has undergone, the English Departnient has been divided into two distinct parts, the University and the
College. Each will be separately ad-

Dr. William H. Welch Was
elected president of the Tudor
and Stuart Club to succeed Dr.
Wilford Pirt Mustard at the club
election last Wednesday night.
Dr. Kemp Malone is to follow Dr.
Edwin Greenlaw as vice-president. Other officers elected were:
Dr. Wight, curator, and Ralph
Kirkley, secretary-treasurer. Dr.
French, faculty member, Reese
Marsh, graduate member; Richard Griffith and Evans Rodgers
were elected to the board of governors.
After the elections an inkstand
was presented to Dr. Raney, retiring university) librarian, who
goes to Chicago soon. Dr. Raney
is a charter member of the club
and also helped in designing the
present club rooms. He stated
that the club now has at least one
of every edition of Spencer, now
in print.

0. D. K. To Initiate
New Men At Assembly
Public initiation of new members to Omicron Delta -Kappa,
honorary society, will be held at
this Thursday's assembly. The
private initiation will follow that
night. Major Enoch Barton Garey,
president of St. John's College,
will be the principal speaker at
the assembly and guest of honor
at the private initiation.
Each of the neophytes will receive the laurel leaf, the emblem
Df victory from J. Henry Jarrett,

NEW FINANCIAL POLICY
INSTITUTED BY JUNE
WEEK COMMITTEE
Actual Ticket Expense Reduced; Caution Money to Be Redeemed in
Different Way

The financial policy of the 1927
June Week Committee will be operated in several respects on a different plan. from former years. The
committee is arranging a program
of as many diversified and attractive events for the entire student
body. Their schedule is based on
the desire to maintain a low ticket
price and, at the same time, be able
to afford an elaborate arrangement
in all details. Though the events
on the program are quite similar
to former years, A more detailed
elaboration is being planned; and it
is felt quite certain that the support
of the student body will warrant
such an expenditure.
Price Remains Same

The price of tickets for under
graduates will be fifteen dollars per
couple for all events on the program. Although this is the price
charged last year the actual cost is
reduced for each student, as the refreshments will be included in this
price. The committee feels that it
is appropriate to include all refreshments in the tickets. This concession will, of course, involve an
extra expenditure for the committee, but it is' felt that the general
will be appealing
satisfaction
enough to increase the sale of tickets and thus compensate Lor the ad
ditional expenditure.
Caution Money Used

Every undergraduate who can
spare the time at the university will
be able to afford the means of attending June Week. The caution
money card will be redeemed as
part credit toward the purchase of
a ticket. The redemption procedure, however, will differ from last
year. Each student, upon securing
the'required signatures will endorse
the card and present it to the treas
urer of the June Week Committee
The bearer will thus receive credit
for the value of his card, paying
only the balance due for the price
of the ticket. These cards will be
accepted at the Barn prior to the
week of exams on *days to be announced later. This plan differs
from last year in that the committee will be able to secure the cards
within a few days and in turn receive the receipts from the treas-

PRICE,5 CENTS

JAY RUNNERS PLACE
AT PENN RELAYS
Johns Hopkins trackmen
placed in only one event at
the annual games held by
the University of Pennsylvania, when the relay team,
compcise4 of Scow, Hemmeter, W. Scheidt and Zepp,
finished third in the Class-A
one-mile relay championship.
Captain Gwinn and Schiebel, the other Black and
Blue representatives to Philadelphia were unplaced in
their event, the two-mile
run. Cox, of Penn State,
intercollegiate cross-country
champion and- winner of this
event last year, repeated his
former triumph.
HOPKINS DEBATERS BEAT
NORTH CAROLINA
Thompson and Gardiner Win Decision
Over Southern Team

"Victory for one team and a
consolation prize for the other"
was the manner in which Alvin
Cartis, presiding at the HopkinsNorth Carolina debate at Chapel
Hill last Friday night, characterized the 2-1 decision -of the judges
in favor of the visiting negative
team. The subject of the intercollegiate debate was: Resolved,
That the United States Should
Adopt Uniform Marriage and Divorce Laws.
Meagre Audience

The debate, held in Gerrard
Hall, on the University of North
Carolina campus at Chapel Hill,
was attended by twenty-five or
thirty listeners. Carolina was
represented by Thomas Capel and
H. B. Parker, who upheld the
affirmative side of the question.
J. Cary Thompson and Norman
B. Gardiner, Jr., debated for Hopkins. Chairman Cartis, in addressing the visitors after the debate said:
"We trust that our guests have
enjoyed their visit here; that they
will return whenever possible;
and that the cordial relations
which have always existed between Hopkins and Carolina will
be continued through years to
come."
Guests of Kappa Alpha

The Hopkins team reached
Chapel Hill at about eleven
o'clock Friday morning, after a
night's ride on 'the train from
Baltimore. They were entertained by the Kappa Alpha fraternity.
Following a stroll about the campus, Thompson and Gardiner witnessed the Carolina-Davidson
baseball game, in which Westmoreland, pitching for Carolina,
held the Wildcats hitless and
scoreless. -When the debate was
over, the Hopkins team attended
the Pi Phi dance in Durham.
Rebuttals Short

CHAMPION JAYS SINK
SWARTHMORE TWELVE
Game Played Almost Entirely in
Pennsylvania Territory
SEASON'S HIGHEST SCORE
Few Garnet Scoring Chances on
Slippery Field

Graduate Manager of
Athletics Resigns
Norman Chase Keyes,
graduate manager of athletics, has tendered his resignation to the Athletic Council. The reasons assigned
for his action have not, as
yet, been made public. Action on this resignation will
be deferred until the next
meeting of the Athletic
Council.
Swarthmore's lacrosse twelve
went down to a crushing defeat
at the hands of the Hopkins stickmen, last Saturday, by a score of
15 to 1. In that contest the Blue
Jay twelve showed more promise
of annexing another intercollegiate championship than at any
other time this year. Swarthmore was simply outclassed and
before five minutes of the game
had passed it was merely a question of how many goals Hopkins
would score before the end. The
Jay stickmen scored three goals
before the ball passed the center
of the field and when it did the
Jay defense cleared the ball out
so quickly that the Swarthmore
attack hardly had the ball in their
sticks.
Swarthmore Slow
From the initial face off it was apparent that the Garnet defense
was slow and unweildly and
would be no match for the Hopkins attack. The muddy condition of the field did not seem to
hamper the Jay stickmen and they
scored at will throughout the entire game.
Judging from the brand of lacrosse displayed by Swarthmore's
all-American goal keeper, it seems
that Laurie Cox, the redoubtable
Syracuse coach, must have picked
the all-American team from box

scores which gave the credit of a
rather good defense to a very
mediocre goal keeper. Hopkins.
fans predict that a new choice
will be made this year.
Ray Fin's admirable'playing in
goal was the most notable feature
of the game.

Pourboire
"Iolanthe," the second Gilbert and Sullivan comic opera to
be produced by the Play Arts Guild this season, is a show that
any lover of the combined works of these two Englishmen should
not miss.
We do not believe that this performance is as well done as yet
as "Patience" but one must remember that "Iolanthe" was put
on in a much more hurried fashion than the first Gilbert and
Sullivan presentation at the Guild Theatre.
And then having seen Winthrop Ames' production of
"Tolanthe" we could not help but compare these two performances;
an altogether unfair comparison, as the Play Arts Guild is an
amateur organization.
This comic opera is a most delightful one, the tunes of "GoodMorrow, Good Mother," "Nine Shall Part Us," "When All
Night Long," "Oh, Foolish Fay," and "Up in the Air, Sky High,"
being familiar, more or less, to nearly everybody.
Burt B. Royce, Jr., as the Earl of Mountarat, was excellent.
In fact, to our way of thinking, he did his part (no play on words
intended, Dr. French) better than any other actor.
Portraying the role of Phyllis, Miss Mary Bokee sang and
acted quite well, but Mr. Donald Kirkley, as The Lord Chancellor,
was somewhat of a disappointment. After his capital performance in "Patience," as one of the poets, we had expected him to
be almost perfect. Probably our disappointment can be based
on the fact that we saw Ernest I,awford take this part in Winthrop Ames' presentation in a flawless manner.
The settings in the second act were fine, but those in the opening act were very amateurish. And the costume of Private Willis
was worse than a R. 0. T. C. uniform. Also something ought to
be done about Mr. Kirkley's wig, which, besides being extremely
dirty, does not fit him at all well and on sundry occasions the
audience is allowed to see the frightful looking lining.
In presenting "Iolanthe," The Play Arts Guild has attempted
a great undertaking, but for an amateur group, however, they have
done nobly, although we consider it inferior to the same organization's presentation of "Patience."

JUST HOW FAR SHOULD THE
HONOR SYSTEM GO?
The honor system at Johns Hopkins has been acclaimed
as a practical success. No serious violations have been manifest, and offenders have been punished quietly but effectively.
It is undoubtedly a tradition which does more toward promoting Hopkins consciousness in students than any other force
on the campus.
A problem which has thrust its head forward lately,
however, is where the ramifications of the system should end.
Does the mere fulfilling of the obligation to hand in work
under one's own name which actually is one's own and the
strict adherence to honesty in quizzes and examinations absolve one of his duties under the system? The University
Handbook has said in part for the last three or four years:
"The scope of the system is broad. It charges every student
of the Johns Hopkins University to exhibit in his college life
all the qualities of a gentleman." And this interpretation has
ostensibly been approved by the Student Council..
Now if this be the accepted interpretation of the Honor
System, certain other, less important points of honor become
involved. For example, it is the duty of a student to consider
the rights of his fellow in regard to volumes placed upon the
reserve shelf in the library. He should not take out a book
for which there is a large demand without signing for it, nor
should he take such a book from the library for hours at a
time without using it. This obligation has been so flagrantly
abused this year that some professors have been forced to
arrange schedules for their classes as to when the students
may use reserve books.
It has been claimed that attempts to enlarge the scope
system to such picayunish matters as reserve shelf
theof
books would in themselves be harmful to the system because
the flaws of human nature would soon cause it to break down.
It has also been claimed that reference to existing weaknesses
in the system are harmful because of psychological reasons.
We cannot support this view. We believe that an occasional
boost is a healthy thing for the very reason that human nature
is what it is.
Why has the Honor System failed at other colleges?
Hopkins men are not a sanctified lot who are incapable of
transgression. They are just as susceptible to the pleadings
of their baser selves as are other men. But they have the
spirit of the Honor System constantly instilled and renewed
in them.
If minor violations are winked at or even disregarded, it
is easily conceivable that major ones will be attempted. Keep
the scope of the Honor System broad, and make it reach every
action that concerns you and any of your contacts with the
University. We do not believe in trying to stick to the Honor
System in examinations and letting it drop in other matters.

Apparently another student is a follower of George Jean
Nathan, for we have a contribution of a list of statements from a
contributor who signs his list, G. E. B., Jr. We were forced to
use the "blue pencil" on several of his assertions, fearing that
they might not meet with the approval of our editor.
That Norman Chase Keyes has twenty tickets printed in the
seasot.i ticket book, when only fifteen are actually needed, in order
to give students the impression that they are getting a lot for their
money.
That each year the freshman class grows worse and worse.
That if a class should walk out of the room at thirty-five
minutes after the hour and the prof. should arrive thirty-six minutes after, the professor is sure to wreak his revenge by giving a
quiz the next day.
That it is impossible to handshake certain professors.
That the Baltimore police are just as much a bunch of "meanon the subject of bonfires as the Annapolis "coppers" are
regarding banquets.
That all of the hundred and one foreign magazines from
Spitzagonia, Heligoland and Zanzibar in the library are a waste
of money and should be promptly thrown out of the periodical
alcove so t- hat subscriptions might be forwarded to such journals
as Life, Judge, Hot Dog and Captain Billy's Whiz-Bang.
That the Cotillon Club keys are "all wet," just as they should
be.
D. H. M.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1927
JAYS INAUGURATE TENNIS
SEASON TODAY
North Carolina to Oppose Black and
Blue in Opening Match

Hopkins' varsity tennis team
will meet the University of North
Carolina at Homewood today.
George Hebner, captain of the
team, expects the North Carolinians to furnish noteworthy resistance, but predicts a Blue Jay win.
The unsatisfactory weather
which prevailed during the earlier part of last week forced the
canceling of matches with St.
Johns and Catholic University.
However, the inclement weather conditions did not wholly preclude the team's working out late
on Wednesday, Thursday and
Friday of last week. Considering
the weather the team has had to
put up with, Hebner is satisfied
With the players' condition. Many
of the men have played indoors
throughout the winter. In practice matches Hebner, Polan and
Levenstein have shown up best,
although more practice and playing is needed to put them in their
best form. Hope is held out for
Letter weather this week.
A match, with the _Suburban
Club is listed on the schedule
for this Saturday. Since the Navy
plays lacrosse at Homewood that
day, the match may be called off.
There is the possibility that the
Suburbans will be played in the
morning, however.
At the present writing, the
spring tennis tournament is making a fight against the terrific
weather that descended on the
city last week, with but partial
success.
However, it is promised that if
the rainy season comes to an end
this week, the tournament will be
run off in an expeditious manner
to make up for lost time.

Frosh-Soph Classes
Back Benefit Dance
Following last week's assembly a
combined meeting of the Freshman
and Sophomore classes was called
for the purpose of announcing a
plan whereby the two classes might
defray expenses created by the "Annapolis affair."
John Pennington Eldridge, chairman of the committee to consider
these plans, spoke of the impracticability of a theater party, because
of the low percentage of receipts allowed. The next idea advanced was
to have a dance at one of the downtown hotels. This however proved
impossible because of advanced
bookings. After some discussion, it
ryas decided that the only practical
thing to have would be a dance.
The announcement was then made
that a dance would be held on Saturday evening, May 7, in the C. E.
hall. The price will be $1.50 stag
or couple. "Bob" Iula and his orchestra will furnish the music.
Mr. Guinot, Annapolitan caterer,
having received no reply from either
of the classes, has sent a letter to
Dr. Goodnow, concerning the payment of $126.40 due him because of
his activity in the affair.
Both Philip Ness, president of the
Sophomore class, and John Eldridge
stressed the importance of supporting this affair by the members of
both classes.
As this is the only Hopkins dance
On this date, it is hoped that the
Classes will have the support of the
entire student body.

Seven Delegates
Attend "Y" Dance
Seven delegates of the Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. arrived at Sherwood Forest last Friday evening to
attend the Interstate Cabinet Training Conference. Cabinet members
of the Christian Associations of colleges and normal schools in Maryland, Delaware, and the District of
Columbia attended. The training
conference is an annual affair, designed to give spiritual, as well as
technical training in the various
phases of Association work. The
program, prepared by a business
committee of which Eugene A.
Schaal was an active member, ar
ranged for speeches, discussion
groups, worship services, and recreation, which kept the delegates busy
until they left late Sunday afternoon. Lowell S. Ensor, President
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., was
chairman of the conference.
The students who made the trip
were L. S. Ensor, C. R. Mengers,
H. Klemme, G. K. Reiblich, E. F.
Dowell, J. Markle, and P. Hall.

practice started yesterday with

will last for approximately
three weeks, is for the purpose
of allowing .Coach Van Orman to get a line on the new
men. Practice will be held
every Wednesday and Friday
at 4:00 P. M. Candidates
will report at Homewood
Field.

Dr. Kemp Malone, who has been
a resident of the Dormitory for
three years was married Thursday
and sails for Europe to-day. Dr:
Malone plans to travel this summer and return to the university in
the fall. He is one of the few men
in the Dormitory who has been able
to command the respect of the residents and at the same time enjoy
the often childish amusements of
the undergraduates.

DR, Li WARDLAW MILES
TO BE ENGLISH HEAD
Former Head-master of Gilman
Succeeds Dr. French
DEPARTMENT REORGANIZED

Only Two Courses Offered to
Students in College
Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, formerly
head-master of the Gilman Country
School and now a lecturer at this
University, has been appointed to
succeed Dr. John C. French as Collegiate Professor of English. Dr.
Miles' appointment and,several other
major changes in the department of
English are the result 6f a complete
reorganization which that department has recently undergone in the
establishment of the New Plan,
Which the University is gradually
adopting.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 3, 1927

CANE CLUB ELECTS
FIVE NEW MEMBERS
Miller Sherwood, Emmert
Stuart, Donald Hiss, Heyward Boyce and Stewart
Hawkes were elected members of the Cane Club last
week. The customary tapping and initiation was held
Monday at noon.
Following the ceremonies
on the upper quadrangle the
members of the club held a
luncheon followed by a
dance that night.
Sherwood, Stuart and
Hiss are members of the
sophomore class while Boyce
is a senior and Hawkes a
graduate student.

Tudor-Stuart Club
Elects New Officers

Hopkins Graduate

Dr. Miles received _his_A. B. at
Johns Hopkins in 1894. He later
studied medicine at the University
of Maryland, and received his degree there. Finding himself more in
Sympathy with the study of literature than of medicine, he returned
to this University, where he received
his doctor's degree in literature in
1902.
After securing this degree here,
Dr. Miles taught for a while at the.
Country School. Later he went to
Princeton where he was instructor
and then preceptor in English until
the outbreak of the World War.
Serving with the American forces
in France as a captain, he was
awarded the Congressional Medal,
for distinguished bravery.
Returns to City

After the Armistice, when he had
sufficiently recovered from wounds
suffered during hostilities, he became head-master of Gilman Country School from which position he
resigned last June. For the past
Year he has been lecturing at St.
John's College and here.
Dr. Miles will head the College
Department of English and be assisted by two instructors and five
student assistants. As a result of the
complete reorganization, which it
has undergone, the English Departnient has been divided into two distinct parts, the University and the
College. Each will be separately ad-

Dr. William H. Welch Was
elected president of the Tudor
and Stuart Club to succeed Dr.
Wilford Pirt Mustard at the club
election last Wednesday night.
Dr. Kemp Malone is to follow Dr.
Edwin Greenlaw as vice-president. Other officers elected were:
Dr. Wight, curator, and Ralph
Kirkley, secretary-treasurer. Dr.
French, faculty member, Reese
Marsh, graduate member; Richard Griffith and Evans Rodgers
were elected to the board of governors.
After the elections an inkstand
was presented to Dr. Raney, retiring university) librarian, who
goes to Chicago soon. Dr. Raney
is a charter member of the club
and also helped in designing the
present club rooms. He stated
that the club now has at least one
of every edition of Spencer, now
in print.

0. D. K. To Initiate
New Men At Assembly
Public initiation of new members to Omicron Delta -Kappa,
honorary society, will be held at
this Thursday's assembly. The
private initiation will follow that
night. Major Enoch Barton Garey,
president of St. John's College,
will be the principal speaker at
the assembly and guest of honor
at the private initiation.
Each of the neophytes will receive the laurel leaf, the emblem
Df victory from J. Henry Jarrett,

NEW FINANCIAL POLICY
INSTITUTED BY JUNE
WEEK COMMITTEE
Actual Ticket Expense Reduced; Caution Money to Be Redeemed in
Different Way

The financial policy of the 1927
June Week Committee will be operated in several respects on a different plan. from former years. The
committee is arranging a program
of as many diversified and attractive events for the entire student
body. Their schedule is based on
the desire to maintain a low ticket
price and, at the same time, be able
to afford an elaborate arrangement
in all details. Though the events
on the program are quite similar
to former years, A more detailed
elaboration is being planned; and it

HOPKINS DEBATERS BEAT
NORTH CAROLINA
Thompson and Gardiner Win Decision
Over Southern Team

"Victory for one team and a
consolation prize for the other"
was the manner in which Alvin
Cartis, presiding at the HopkinsNorth Carolina debate at Chapel
Hill last Friday night, characterized the 2-1 decision -of the judges
in favor of the visiting negative
team. The subject of the intercollegiate debate was: Resolved,
That the United States Should
Adopt Uniform Marriage and Divorce Laws.
Meagre Audience

The debate, held in Gerrard
Hall, on the University of North
Carolina campus at Chapel Hill,
was attended by twenty-five or
thirty listeners. Carolina was
represented by Thomas Capel and
H. B. Parker, who upheld the
affirmative side of the question.
J. Cary Thompson and Norman
B. Gardiner, Jr., debated for Hopkins. Chairman Cartis, in addressing the visitors after the debate said:
"We trust that our guests have
enjoyed their visit here; that they
will return whenever possible;
and that the cordial relations
which have always existed between Hopkins and Carolina will
be continued through years to
come."
Guests of Kappa Alpha

The Hopkins team reached
Chapel Hill at about eleven
o'clock Friday morning, after a
night's ride on 'the train from
Baltimore. They were entertained by the Kappa Alpha fraternity.
Following a stroll about the campus, Thompson and Gardiner witnessed the Carolina-Davidson
baseball game, in which Westmoreland, pitching for Carolina,
held the Wildcats hitless and
scoreless. -When the debate was
over, the Hopkins team attended
the Pi Phi dance in Durham.
Rebuttals Short

SEASON'S HIGHEST SCORE
Few Garnet Scoring Chances on
Slippery Field

Graduate Manager of
Athletics Resigns
Norman Chase Keyes,
graduate manager of athletics, has tendered his resignation to the Athletic Council. The reasons assigned
for his action have not, as
yet, been made public. Action on this resignation will
be deferred until the next
meeting of the Athletic
Council.
Swarthmore's lacrosse twelve
went down to a crushing defeat
at the hands of the Hopkins stickmen, last Saturday, by a score of
15 to 1. In that contest the Blue
Jay twelve showed more promise
of annexing another intercollegiate championship than at any
other time this year. Swarthmore was simply outclassed and
before five minutes of the game
had passed it was merely a question of how many goals Hopkins
would score before the end. The
Jay stickmen scored three goals
before the ball passed the center
of the field and when it did the
Jay defense cleared the ball out
so quickly that the Swarthmore
attack hardly had the ball in their
sticks.
Swarthmore Slow
From the initial face off it was apparent that the Garnet defense
was slow and unweildly and
would be no match for the Hopkins attack. The muddy condition of the field did not seem to
hamper the Jay stickmen and they
scored at will throughout the entire game.
Judging from the brand of lacrosse displayed by Swarthmore's
all-American goal keeper, it seems
that Laurie Cox, the redoubtable
Syracuse coach, must have picked
the all-American team from box

scores which gave the credit of a
rather good defense to a very
mediocre goal keeper. Hopkins.
fans predict that a new choice
will be made this year.
Ray Fin's admirable'playing in
goal was the most notable feature
of the game.

Pourboire
"Iolanthe," the second Gilbert and Sullivan comic opera to
be produced by the Play Arts Guild this season, is a show that
any lover of the combined works of these two Englishmen should
not miss.
We do not believe that this performance is as well done as yet
as "Patience" but one must remember that "Iolanthe" was put
on in a much more hurried fashion than the first Gilbert and
Sullivan presentation at the Guild Theatre.
And then having seen Winthrop Ames' production of
"Tolanthe" we could not help but compare these two performances;
an altogether unfair comparison, as the Play Arts Guild is an
amateur organization.
This comic opera is a most delightful one, the tunes of "GoodMorrow, Good Mother," "Nine Shall Part Us," "When All
Night Long," "Oh, Foolish Fay," and "Up in the Air, Sky High,"
being familiar, more or less, to nearly everybody.
Burt B. Royce, Jr., as the Earl of Mountarat, was excellent.
In fact, to our way of thinking, he did his part (no play on words
intended, Dr. French) better than any other actor.
Portraying the role of Phyllis, Miss Mary Bokee sang and
acted quite well, but Mr. Donald Kirkley, as The Lord Chancellor,
was somewhat of a disappointment. After his capital performance in "Patience," as one of the poets, we had expected him to
be almost perfect. Probably our disappointment can be based
on the fact that we saw Ernest I,awford take this part in Winthrop Ames' presentation in a flawless manner.
The settings in the second act were fine, but those in the opening act were very amateurish. And the costume of Private Willis
was worse than a R. 0. T. C. uniform. Also something ought to
be done about Mr. Kirkley's wig, which, besides being extremely
dirty, does not fit him at all well and on sundry occasions the
audience is allowed to see the frightful looking lining.
In presenting "Iolanthe," The Play Arts Guild has attempted
a great undertaking, but for an amateur group, however, they have
done nobly, although we consider it inferior to the same organization's presentation of "Patience."

JUST HOW FAR SHOULD THE
HONOR SYSTEM GO?
The honor system at Johns Hopkins has been acclaimed
as a practical success. No serious violations have been manifest, and offenders have been punished quietly but effectively.
It is undoubtedly a tradition which does more toward promoting Hopkins consciousness in students than any other force
on the campus.
A problem which has thrust its head forward lately,
however, is where the ramifications of the system should end.
Does the mere fulfilling of the obligation to hand in work
under one's own name which actually is one's own and the
strict adherence to honesty in quizzes and examinations absolve one of his duties under the system? The University
Handbook has said in part for the last three or four years:
"The scope of the system is broad. It charges every student
of the Johns Hopkins University to exhibit in his college life
all the qualities of a gentleman." And this interpretation has
ostensibly been approved by the Student Council..
Now if this be the accepted interpretation of the Honor
System, certain other, less important points of honor become
involved. For example, it is the duty of a student to consider
the rights of his fellow in regard to volumes placed upon the
reserve shelf in the library. He should not take out a book
for which there is a large demand without signing for it, nor
should he take such a book from the library for hours at a
time without using it. This obligation has been so flagrantly
abused this year that some professors have been forced to
arrange schedules for their classes as to when the students
may use reserve books.
It has been claimed that attempts to enlarge the scope
system to such picayunish matters as reserve shelf
theof
books would in themselves be harmful to the system because
the flaws of human nature would soon cause it to break down.
It has also been claimed that reference to existing weaknesses
in the system are harmful because of psychological reasons.
We cannot support this view. We believe that an occasional
boost is a healthy thing for the very reason that human nature
is what it is.
Why has the Honor System failed at other colleges?
Hopkins men are not a sanctified lot who are incapable of
transgression. They are just as susceptible to the pleadings
of their baser selves as are other men. But they have the
spirit of the Honor System constantly instilled and renewed
in them.
If minor violations are winked at or even disregarded, it
is easily conceivable that major ones will be attempted. Keep
the scope of the Honor System broad, and make it reach every
action that concerns you and any of your contacts with the
University. We do not believe in trying to stick to the Honor
System in examinations and letting it drop in other matters.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 3, 1927
JAYS INAUGURATE TENNIS
SEASON TODAY
North Carolina to Oppose Black and
Blue in Opening Match

Hopkins' varsity tennis team
will meet the University of North
Carolina at Homewood today.
George Hebner, captain of the
team, expects the North Carolinians to furnish noteworthy resistance, but predicts a Blue Jay win.
The unsatisfactory weather
which prevailed during the earlier part of last week forced the
canceling of matches with St.
Johns and Catholic University.
However, the inclement weather conditions did not wholly preclude the team's working out late
on Wednesday, Thursday and
Friday of last week. Considering
the weather the team has had to
put up with, Hebner is satisfied
With the players' condition. Many
of the men have played indoors
throughout the winter. In practice matches Hebner, Polan and
Levenstein have shown up best,
although more practice and playing is needed to put them in their
best form. Hope is held out for
Letter weather this week.
A match, with the _Suburban
Club is listed on the schedule
for this Saturday. Since the Navy
plays lacrosse at Homewood that
day, the match may be called off.
There is the possibility that the
Suburbans will be played in the
morning, however.
At the present writing, the
spring tennis tournament is making a fight against the terrific
weather that descended on the
city last week, with but partial
success.
However, it is promised that if
the rainy season comes to an end
this week, the tournament will be
run off in an expeditious manner
to make up for lost time.

Frosh-Soph Classes
Back Benefit Dance
Following last week's assembly a
combined meeting of the Freshman
and Sophomore classes was called
for the purpose of announcing a
plan whereby the two classes might
defray expenses created by the "Annapolis affair."
John Pennington Eldridge, chairman of the committee to consider
these plans, spoke of the impracticability of a theater party, because
of the low percentage of receipts allowed. The next idea advanced was
to have a dance at one of the downtown hotels. This however proved
impossible because of advanced
bookings. After some discussion, it
ryas decided that the only practical
thing to have would be a dance.
The announcement was then made
that a dance would be held on Saturday evening, May 7, in the C. E.
hall. The price will be $1.50 stag
or couple. "Bob" Iula and his orchestra will furnish the music.
Mr. Guinot, Annapolitan caterer,
having received no reply from either
of the classes, has sent a letter to
Dr. Goodnow, concerning the payment of $126.40 due him because of
his activity in the affair.
Both Philip Ness, president of the
Sophomore class, and John Eldridge
stressed the importance of supporting this affair by the members of
both classes.
As this is the only Hopkins dance
On this date, it is hoped that the
Classes will have the support of the
entire student body.

Seven Delegates
Attend "Y" Dance
Seven delegates of the Johns Hopkins Y. M. C. A. arrived at Sherwood Forest last Friday evening to
attend the Interstate Cabinet Training Conference. Cabinet members
of the Christian Associations of colleges and normal schools in Maryland, Delaware, and the District of
Columbia attended. The training
conference is an annual affair, designed to give spiritual, as well as
technical training in the various
phases of Association work. The
program, prepared by a business
committee of which Eugene A.
Schaal was an active member, ar
ranged for speeches, discussion
groups, worship services, and recreation, which kept the delegates busy
until they left late Sunday afternoon. Lowell S. Ensor, President
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., was
chairman of the conference.
The students who made the trip
were L. S. Ensor, C. R. Mengers,
H. Klemme, G. K. Reiblich, E. F.
Dowell, J. Markle, and P. Hall.

FOOTBALL PRACTICE
GETS UNDER WAY
With "Charley" Wolbert
putting the candidates through
their paces, spring football
practice started yesterday with
a vim. This practice, which
will last for approximately
three weeks, is for the purpose
of allowing .Coach Van Orman to get a line on the new
men. Practice will be held
every Wednesday and Friday
at 4:00 P. M. Candidates
will report at Homewood
Field.

Hunted by Man

"At another time, I was told that
one of my laborers, crazed by liquor,
was hunting for me with blood in
his eye and a pistol in his hand. I
was advised to keep inside, but
knowing that my prestige with the
men under me would suffer if I did
I told my well-meaning advisor to
inform the gentleman that he would
find me, not •indoors but in front
of the hotel,
"As a matter of fact, I failed to
ever see the man again, but afterward learned that he was a gunman
of no mean repute. He had three
murders to his credit, in Montana
before he came after me.

DORM DOINGS
Dr. Kemp Malone, who has been
a resident of the Dormitory for
three years was married Thursday
and sails for Europe to-day. Dr:
Malone plans to travel this summer and return to the university in
the fall. He is one of the few men
in the Dormitory who has been able
to command the respect of the residents and at the same time enjoy
the often childish amusements of
the undergraduates.
